title: 114_hr2518
content: The Act titled "Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015" amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to include new requirements for program participation agreements. This includes providing institutional and financial assistance information to students. Section 485 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to align institutional reporting requirements with IPEDS data metrics. The Secretary will issue guidance on duplicative data metrics within 6 months of the Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015. Institutions must link to an institutional reporting website within 5 years of the Act. Institutions must provide a prominently displayed link on their website to a specified website, as determined by the Secretary under the Higher Education Act of 1965. SEC. 4 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits amending the database of student information and introduces new reporting requirements under section 493E. Each institution of higher education must submit data to the Secretary for the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System. The Secretary will provide guidance on data submission within a year of the Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015. Every 5 years, the Secretary will review the data categories required for submission. Additional student classifications may be established. The Secretary will establish common definitions and submission requirements for institutions under the Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015. Institutions must submit student-level components of IPEDS for coding and reporting on students in remedial education. The Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015 requires institutions to submit data for calculating student-level components of IPEDS, including degree-seeking status and certificate pursuit. Additionally, new outcome metrics will be established by the Secretary, at both institutional and program-specific levels, within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015 mandates institutions to provide data on student-level components of IPEDS, including degree-seeking status and certificate pursuit. The Act also requires the establishment of new outcome metrics by the Secretary at institutional and program-specific levels. This includes data on the percentage of students receiving various types of financial aid, average Federal loan debt upon graduation, debt of non-completing students, and student transfer rates by sector. The Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015 requires institutions to provide data on student transfer rates by sector, continuation to higher education, and percentage of students receiving financial aid. The Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015 mandates institutions to report outcome measures, including student-level components disaggregated by student types such as Pell Grant recipients and loan recipients. The Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015 requires reporting of outcome measures, including student types like veterans or members of the Armed Forces receiving educational assistance. Data on enrollment status is also included. The Student Right to Know Before You Go Act of 2015 mandates reporting outcome measures for different student categories, such as first-time, full-time students, part-time students, and non-first-time students. It also includes enrollment intensity options like full-time, part-time, or mixed enrollment, as well as earning metrics established by the Secretary. The Secretary, in collaboration with the Commissioner of Social Security, will establish earning metrics using IPEDS student data. This will include median annual earnings and employment data broken down by educational program, credential, institution, and state of employment, as well as disaggregated earnings over different time periods. The Secretary will consult with State offices to establish earning metrics using student data from public and private institutions. This includes median annual earnings and employment data broken down by educational program, credential, institution, and state of employment over various time periods. The Secretary will issue guidelines to higher education institutions for amending annual privacy notices to reference data collection required under this section. Personally identifiable information collected must only be used as authorized by this section or permitted for disclosure. No unauthorized federal actions are allowed. No federal action can be taken against an individual based on data collected for the system developed under this section. Personally identifiable information collected or retained under this section is immune from legal process and cannot be used as evidence without consent. The data system developed under this section cannot be used by institutions of higher education to take action against an individual. Requests for personally identifiable information can be made by the individual or on their behalf, and the Secretary must provide the data upon verification of identity. The Secretary must use appropriate statistical disclosure for public reporting and disclosure requirements. The Secretary must use statistical disclosure techniques to prevent the release of personally identifiable information in the data. Aggregate data will be posted on the Department's website, and non-personally identifiable data may be available for research purposes with approval. The Secretary will provide aggregate student outcome data to institutions of higher education and States for institutional improvement and program evaluation. Data collected under this section will not be sold to third parties. Measures will be taken to ensure comparability of data metrics for 5 years after the enactment of the Student Right to Know. The Secretary will publish student-level components of IPEDS as they were before the enactment of the Student Right to Know Act of 2015. It is illegal to willfully disclose personally identifiable information from the data system, punishable by up to 5 years in prison or fines. The Secretary will establish regulations for data security, including audit capability, access controls, and data quality. Personally identifiable information includes student names, family names, and addresses. The curr_chunk discusses the various types of information that are considered personally identifiable, including addresses, social security numbers, and other indirect identifiers. This information can be used to identify a specific student with reasonable certainty. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2016 through 2024 is provided to carry out this section.
